Perhaps you are looking for this http://pytorch.org/docs/tensors.html?highlight=cuda#torch.Tensor.cuda ?

In short, when you move a tensor to the GPU with .cuda() you can set the destination (which GPU) by simply passing an integer. To use the first GPU, use .cuda(0). The same can be done with everything else CUDA related.

This is also useful to check out, CUDA semantics: http://pytorch.org/docs/notes/cuda.html

Perhaps you are looking for this http://pytorch.org/docs/tensors.html?highlight=cuda#torch.Tensor.cuda ?

In short, when you move a tensor to the GPU with `.cuda()` you can set the destination (which GPU) by simply passing an integer. To use the first GPU, use `.cuda(0)`. The same can be done with everything else CUDA related.

This is also useful to check out, CUDA semantics: http://pytorch.org/docs/notes/cuda.html
